questions.text: Please identify the structure shown in this endoscopic image of the nasopharynx.
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Fossa of Rosenmüller

Deep recess behind the torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Sinus of Morgagni

Gap between the base of the skull and superior pharyngeal constrictor muscle

Passavant’s Ridge

Muscular ridge formed by the superior pharyngeal constrictor, involved in velopharyngeal closure

Rathke’s Pouch

Embryological remnant from which the anterior pituitary gland develops

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought by her mother, with the complaint that the child is experiencing difficulties breathing through her nose. The girl's face appears elongated and lacks expression, and her mouth remains open. Upon examination, it is observed that she has a palate with a high arch and her upper teeth are crowded. An X-ray image is provided for reference. Based on these findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D- Adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: Mark the false statement :

options.label: A
options.text: Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of carotid sheath

options.label: B
options.text: Carotid sheath is formed by investing layer of deep cervical fascia

options.label: C
options.text: Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein

options.label: D
options.text: Common carotid artery divides at the level of lower border of thyroid cartilage

questions.correct_answer: C. Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein
questions.explanation:
Structure Description
Contents Common carotid artery, Internal jugular vein, Vagus nerve (CN X)
Formation Formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia
Location Located in the neck, on both sides of the trachea
Common Carotid Artery Ascends within the sheath, bifurcates into internal and external carotid arteries at the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage
Internal Jugular Vein Lies adjacent to the common carotid artery, carrying deoxygenated blood from the brain, face, and neck
Vagus Nerve (CN X) Travels alongside the carotid artery and vein within the sheath, involved in parasympathetic innervation and various functions in the head and neck
Sympathetic Chain Located posterior to the carotid sheath structures, part of the sympathetic nervous system responsible for fight-or-flight responses

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a patient who has a two-day history of fever, with a neck swelling and displacement of one tonsil towards the midline upon examination?
questions.explanation:
Correct option B

Condition

Description

Common Symptoms

Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess)

Collection of pus between the tonsillar capsule and surrounding tissues

Severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, "hot potato" voice

Parapharyngeal Abscess

Infection in the space behind the tonsil and next to the pharynx

Neck swelling, displacement of tonsil, possible difficulty swallowing

Retropharyngeal Abscess

Infection in the space behind the pharynx and in front of the cervical vertebrae

Neck pain, difficulty swallowing, stiff neck

Tonsillitis

Inflammation of the tonsils

Sore throat, difficulty swallowing, fever

questions.text: From the first pharyngeal arch, which muscle originates among the options provided?
questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior belly of digastric muscle
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- Anterior belly of digastric mu

Pharyngeal Arch

Structures Derived

First Pharyngeal Arch
  • Muscles of Mastication (Masseter, Temporalis, Medial and Lateral Pterygoids)
  • Anterior Belly of Digastric Muscle
  • Mylohyoid Muscle
  • Tensor Tympani Muscle
  • Tensor Veli Palatini Muscle

Second Pharyngeal Arch
  • Muscles of Facial Expression
  • Stylohyoid Muscle
  • Posterior Belly of Digastric Muscle
  • Stapedius Muscle

Third Pharyngeal Arch
  • Stylopharyngeus Muscle

Fourth and Sixth Pharyngeal Arch
  • Muscles of the Pharynx (except Stylopharyngeus)
  • Muscles of the Larynx
  • Cricothyroid Muscle
  • Levator Veli Palatini Muscle
  • Constrictors of the Pharynx (Superior, Middle, and Inferior Constrictors)

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options does not represent a premalignant lesion or condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct option A

Premalignant Lesion/Condition

Description

Associated Risk of Cancer

Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis

Fungal infection caused by Candida species

Not considered premalignant

Oral submucosal fibrosis

Chronic condition with fibrous bands in the oral cavity

Increased risk of oral squamous cell carcinoma

Lichen planus

Autoimmune condition affecting skin and oral mucosa

Associated with increased risk of oral squamous cell carcinoma in some cases

Leukoplakia

White or gray patches on mucous membranes, including oral mucosa

Considered a premalignant lesion with potential for oral cancer development

questions.text: A patient comes with an ulcer on the tongue with a duration of 3 months. On examination, there is a 3.5cm x 2.5 cm lesion with induration of 8mm. There was no lymphadenopathy. What is the stage of this lesion according to 8the AJCC guidelines ?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Tumor (T)

Lymph Nodes (N)

Metastasis (M)

Stage 0

Tis: Carcinoma in situ

N0: No regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

Stage I

T1: Tumor ≤ 2 cm in greatest dimension

N0: No regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

Stage II

T2: Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 4 cm in greatest dimension

N0: No regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

Stage III

T3: Tumor > 4 cm in greatest dimension

N0: No regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

 

or

or

 

 

T1/T2: Tumor with ipsilateral lymph node metastasis

N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node

M0: No distant metastasis

Stage IVA

T4a: Tumor invades adjacent structures

N0/N1/N2: Regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

 

or

or

 

 

T1/T2/T3: Tumor with contralateral lymph node

N2: Multiple ipsilateral or contralateral lymph node metastases

M0: No distant metastasis

 

metastasis

 

 

Stage IVB

T4b: Tumor invades masticator space, pterygoid plates,

Any N: Regional lymph node metastasis

M0: No distant metastasis

 

or skull base

 

 

Stage IVC

Any T: Tumor of any size

Any N: Regional lymph node metastasis

M1: Distant metastasis

questions.text: A patient presents with oral cavity findings are seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient ?

questions.correct_answer: B. Cessation of smoking and do biopsy
questions.explanation:
Lesion

Description

Risk Category

Leukoplakia

White patch or plaque that cannot be scraped off

Potentially premalignant

Erythroplakia

Smooth, red velvety patch in the oral cavity

High risk for dysplasia or malignancy

Oral submucous fibrosis

Chronic, progressive fibrotic condition

Precancerous condition

Verrucous hyperplasia

Proliferative, wart-like growth in the oral cavity

Associated with squamous cell carcinoma

Actinic cheilitis

Sun-induced changes in the lower lip

Premalignant condition

Oral lichen planus

Chronic inflammatory condition affecting mucosa

Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma

Dysplastic nevus

Atypical mole with potential for malignant transformation

Increased risk for melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space ?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Location Located deep within the parapharyngeal space, behind the styloid process of the temporal bone.
Common Causes - Spread of infections from adjacent structures (e.g., tonsils, middle ear).  - Abscess formation.  - Rarely, neoplastic conditions.
Clinical Manifestations - Severe sore throat.  - Trismus (difficulty in mouth opening).  - Pain on swallowing.  - Neck pain.  - Fever and systemic symptoms.  - Cranial nerve involvement (e.g., vocal cord palsy).
Imaging Findings - CT or MRI scans may reveal abscess formation or inflammation in the post-styloid compartment.
Treatment - Antibiotics to manage infection.  - Drainage of abscess if present.  - Pain management.  - Management of any complications (e.g., airway compromise).
Potential Complications - Airway compromise due to severe swelling or abscess. - Extension of infection to adjacent spaces.  - Cranial nerve palsies (e.g., vocal cord palsy).

questions.text: Which structure is typically involved in causing lower lip paralysis following a parotidectomy?
What is the preferred management for a pediatric patient with symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy causing chronic nasal obstruction and sleep apnea?
questions.explanation:
Management of Adenoid Hypertrophy:

Medical Management: (For Mild Cases initially)
  • Breathing exercises
  • Decongestant nasal drops
  • Antihistamines for any nasal allergies
  • Topical Nasal Steroids may reduce adenoid size and improve related symptoms.

Surgical Intervention: (Adenoidectomy)
  • Traditional Methods: Blind curettage adenoidectomy remains common, but it has disadvantages, including unpredictable bleeding and poor access to the choanal adenoid. Hence, Endoscopic management is currently preferred.
  • Direct Vision Techniques:
    • Suction Diathermy
    • Endoscopic Coblation/Microdebridement involves using endoscopy to visualise and allows for precise removal of obstructive adenoid tissue, addressing the underlying issue directly.
    • KTP Laser: Associated with a higher risk of nasopharyngeal stenosis, while the gold laser has not shown this risk.

What is the most common site of ranula?

questions.text: A child with a mild cold who also has adenoid facies has been identified as having chronic adenoid hypertrophy. Which is the best surgical management for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - C

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the yellow arrow in the image.
Which of the following conditions is associated with Hollman miller's sign in the CT image given below?
questions.explanation:
Investigations of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan
  • Investigation of choice; shows tumor size, location, and bony involvement.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Holman-Miller sign (bowing of maxillary wall).

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Evaluates soft tissue and intracranial extension, differentiates between extradural and intradural spread.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Visualizes tumor vascularity, identifies feeding vessels and aids in preoperative embolization to reduce surgical blood loss.

Nasopharyngoscopy

Provides a direct view of the tumor, but biopsy is generally avoided due to high bleeding risk.

Audiometry

Assesses hearing loss caused by Eustachian tube obstruction; establishes baseline and monitors post-treatment hearing.

Biopsy

Biopsy is contraindicated due to risk of profuse bleeding.

questions.text: A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient? [
questions.explanation:
Category

Indications

Management
Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects
 Immediate endoscopic removal
Urgent
  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks
 Observation

questions.text: What would be the next step in managing the symptoms of a 7-year-old child who underwent a tonsillectomy and now presents with snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing, a slight hearing loss, a high arched palate, and a decline in school performance, causing concern to the mother?

A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound compressing the swelling. X-ray of the neck is seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

What is the most probable condition for a 6-year-old child who has not received immunization, presented to the Emergency Room by a concerned mother, experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing? Physical examination reveals the presence of a pseudo membrane on the tonsils that bleeds upon attempted removal, as well as a swollen neck giving a bull-neck appearance.
Which among the following conditions does not result in the development of a grey-white membrane over the tonsils?
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’s angina- Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces.
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces

 
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker’s oral examination. Identify the lesion given.
questions.explanation:
Definition

White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc.

Causes
  • Smoking, tobacco chewing
  • Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking)
  • Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites)
  • Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Common sites
  • Buccal mucosa (most common in India)
  • Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa

Age & Gender
  • Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females.

Clinical types
  • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk
  • Nodular (speckled): White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk
  • Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk

Malignant potential
  • 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation
  • Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations

Treatment
  • Remove causative factors: Spontaneous regression in some cases.
  • Biopsy: For lesions with high malignant potential.
  • Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy: For suspicious or small lesions

questions.text: What is the primary source of arterial supply for the palatine tonsils among the options provided?

options.label: A
options.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

options.label: B
options.text: Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
questions.explanation:
Anatomy of Palatine tonsils

Location

Lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

Surface Extensions

Upwards into the soft palate, downwards into the base of the tongue, and anteriorly into the palatoglossal arch.

Medial Surface Epithelium
  • Stratified squamous epithelium with crypts.
  • Crypta magna, or intratonsillar cleft, is located near the upper part of the tonsil.

Lateral Surface

It is covered by a fibrous capsule separated from the tonsil bed by loose areolar tissue.

Tonsil Bed Muscles

Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

Arterial Supply
  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (main supply)
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Dorsal linguae branches of the lingual artery
  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.

Venous Drainage

It drains into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal venous plexus.

Lymphatic Drainage

Flows into the upper deep cervical nodes.

Sensory Nerve Supply

Lesser palatine branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion (CN V) and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Adenoid Hypertrophy: (Enlargement of the adenoids)

Aetiology
  • Physiological Enlargement: Common in childhood.
  • Chronic Conditions: Recurrent rhinitis, sinusitis, chronic tonsillitis, & allergies.

Clinical Features
  • Nasal Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction leading to mouth breathing and feeding difficulties.
  • Nasal discharge due to choanal obstruction and chronic rhinitis.
  • Sinusitis, Epistaxis & voice changes due to nasal obstruction. (Rhinolalia clausa)
  • Aural Symptoms:
  • Tubal obstruction causing retracted tympanic membrane and CHL.
  • Recurrent acute otitis media and chronic suppurative otitis media.
  • Otitis media with effusion due to intermittent eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Adenoid Facies: Characteristic facial appearance with an elongated face, open mouth, crowded upper teeth, and high-arched palate.
 
  • Pulmonary Hypertension: Potential due to long-standing nasal obstruction.
  • Aprosexia: Difficulty concentrating

Clinical Examination
  • External Nose: Check for skin changes indicating frequent nose rubbing.
  • Nasal Assessment: Halogen light otoscope is used for simple anterior rhinoscopy, which examines the nasal cavity but not the adenoids.
  • Adenoid Assessment:
    • Nasendoscopy: For detailed evaluation, a flexible pediatric endoscope with topical anaesthesia is preferred. It provides an accurate assessment of adenoid size in an outpatient setting.
    • Lateral Soft-Tissue Radiograph: This is useful when endoscopy is not tolerated; it correlates well with endoscopic findings.

questions.text: Involvement of Jugular foramen leads to which of the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of taste from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of tasteand sensation from the anterior ⅔ of the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Loss of sensation from the posterior ⅓ of the tongue
questions.explanation:
Development of tongue and nerve innervation

Aspects

Anterior ⅔ of tongue

Posterior ⅓ of tongue

Posterior most of the tongue

Epithelial Development

Two lingual swellings and a tuberculum impar, made from the mesoderm of 1st arch, fuse to form the anterior ⅔ of tongue.

The hypobranchial arch is formed by the mesoderm of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches and is further divided into cranial and caudal parts. The cranial part of this arch gives rise to the posterior ⅓.

The Caudal parts derived from the hypobranchial arch develop to the posterior part of the tongue

Taste Sensation

Chorda Tympani

Glossopharyngeal nerve (supplies circumvallate papillae)

(Option B)

Internal laryngeal nerve (Branch of Vagus)

Sensory supply

Lingual nerve

Motor Supply

Except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve, all other intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

Muscles

All the Tongue muscles develop from Occipital Somites.

questions.text: What would be your immediate course of action in managing a patient who is experiencing bleeding from the surgical site following a tonsillectomy while in the recovery room?

options.label: A
options.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

options.label: B
options.text: Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa

options.label: C
options.text: Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.correct_answer: A. Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the v
